title: Children’s Play in Early Childhood Education
description: This course aims to introduce the history, nature, theories and practices of play in early childhood curriculum. It covers the following topics: Values of play for cognitive and social emotional developments; promoting children’s creative expression in art, music and drama through play; fostering playful learning through formal and informal, indoor and outdoor activities; play and technology; teachers’ and students’ perspectives on play; planning and arranging the creative environment and materials for play; designing play-based curriculum, and assessing play.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. Grasp the distinctive features of different kinds and types of play: 2. Understand the values of play in developing children holistically; 3. Promote play through staging playful environment; 4. Design play-based curriculum; and 5. Assessing children’s learning in and through play.
syllabus: The course will cover the following topics: 1. history and nature of play; 2. theories and practices of play; 3. values of play for cognitive and social emotional development; 4. play and creative expression in art and music; 5. drama and play; 6. indoor and outdoor play; 7. play and technology 8. teachers’ role in play; 9. play environment and resources; 10. designing play-based curriculum; and 11. assessing play and children’s development.  本科的課程內容包括： 1. 遊戲的歷史和性質； 2. 遊戲的理論和實踐； 3. 遊戲對認知和社會情緒發展的價值； 4. 遊戲與藝術和音樂的創意表達； 5. 戲劇和遊戲； 6. 戶內和戶外的遊戲； 7. 遊戲與科技； 8. 教師在遊戲中的角色； 9. 遊戲的環境和資源； 10. 遊戲為本的課程設計；及 11. 遊戲中幼兒發展的評估。

title: Language and Literacy Development in Young Children
description: This course is an introduction to the theories of language and literacy development in young children. The stages of language development in early childhood will be covered. The course examines literacy from contemporary perspectives and how young children develop literacy through participating in a range of activities in their family, school and community. Participants will be encouraged to examine critically current practices in literacy education in local settings. They will also explore a range of resources and strategies to support and facilitate literacy learning opportunities for young children.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are expected to: 1. compare and contrast different theories of language and literacy development in young children; 2. describe the stages of language development in young children; 3. explain how young children develop language through engagement with other people and their surroundings; and 4. critique current local practices in developing young children’s language and literacy ability.
syllabus: 1. Child Development： language learning and Communication 2. Early childhood language education in Hong Kong (school, government and society) 3. Theories of Language Development  4. Early childhood language development：getting ready to talk 5. Early childhood language development：getting ready to write 6. Curriculum design and assessment 7. Teaching methods and classroom activities design  8. Creative Picture Book Teaching  9. The Implementation of Whole Language Education

title: Mathematics, Science, and Tech Experiences in Early Childhood
description: This course aims to help participants understand how young children learn mathematics and science by actively constructing knowledge and making connections between new knowledge and prior knowledge. Participants will be provided with opportunities to consolidate their understandings of foundational concepts in mathematics, science and technology. They will also explore various ways to develop appropriate learning activities to foster young children’s development. This will include active exploration and manipulation of concrete materials and technological visualizations.This course will study teaching methods and key sequences for developing young children’s concepts and knowledge in the following: number, space, measurement, chance and data, patterns, body structure and functions, living and nonliving things, plants and animals, energy, water and gas, and simple toys. Participants will be able to master the skills to help young children acquire simple specific skills, such as observing and recording changes, making predictions and assumptions, and classifying objects.
outcome: At the end of the course, participants will: 1. demonstrate an awareness and understanding of concepts in mathematics, science and technology appropriate to the early childhood years; and 2. plan and prepare learning activities and experiences that enhance the development of young children in mathematics, science and technology. 3. Distinguish major theoretical perspectives, characteristics, and practices about learning process of science, math and technology  4. Appraise impacts of technology development on child learning
syllabus: • Concept development in math and science • Basics of Science, Engineering and Technology • Prekindergarten and Kindergarten Concepts and Skills • Early Geometry, Parts and Wholes, and applications of fundamental concepts to science and engineering • Ordering, measurement, and data collection and analysis • Transitioning from Preschool to Kindergarten to Primary  • Mathematics concepts for primary grades • HKECE curriculum in Science and Mathematics • Investigations in primary science  • Case study of Kindergarten Science teaching and learning activity • Integrating the curriculum

title: Leadership and Management in Early Childhood Settings
description: This course provides an introduction to various leadership and management theories for early childhood education practitioners. The application of these theories and knowledge in early childhood education institutions will be illustrated at three different levels: social, school and individual. First, topics on rationale of accountability and quality assurance mechanism, data driven school improvement and matters in preparation for school self-evaluation and external review will be examined. Second, the implementation of school-based management such as resource management, professional development of teachers and team building will be discussed. Third, teacher professionalism and ways to equip early childhood practitioners with sufficient knowledge in order to fulfill their respective roles as school leaders or teacher leaders will be discussed. The course provides participants with conceptual knowledge in leadership and school management that serves as the basis of sustainable development of early childhood education institutions.
outcome: At the end of this course, participants should be able to: 1. understand recent school management reforms in Hong Kong and their impacts on preschools and kindergartens; 2. examine various roles of early childhood teachers in relation to school reforms and school-based management; 3. have basic understanding of various leadership and school management concepts and their application in daily operation of early childhood education institutions;  4. identify areas and directions for school improvement based on information gathered from annual school self-evaluation and external school review;  5. critically reflect on individual competency and school practices by linking theories and practices in the context of early childhood education.

title: Home-School-Community Collaboration for School Development
description: Home-school-community collaboration provides essential resources that teachers can call upon for school improvement. The course aims to help teachers develop the competencies necessary for working with families and communities in order to enhance student learning and school effectiveness. Special emphasis is placed upon better understanding of the dynamics of parent-teacher relationships and the policies and practices of home-school-community collaboration within current educational reforms. Case studies, guest speakers, role play, debate, action plans, and discussion of required readings are woven throughout the sessions in order to prepare teachers to: (i) understand parents' roles in their children's education; (ii) enhance home-school-community communication; (iii) improve parental involvement in school activities; and (iv) build trusting relationships with parents through their community.

title: Aesthetic Experience and Creative Expressions in Early Childhood
description: This course introduces to students the nature of aesthetic experience and its significant role in the early years of human development. The interrelated development of empathetic understanding, imagination, and creativity through the arts will be discussed. Focus will be given to the design of activities that facilitate young children's appreciation and creative expressions of different forms of arts. These forms encompass visual arts (e.g. drawings, paintings, handicraft, sculpture, photography), language arts (e.g. picture books, poems, fairy tales), expressive arts (e.g. music, dance, drama), and the integrated arts. All the above forms could be actualized in various kinds of play, which serve as an ideal form for creative expressions. With the view to uncovering the dynamics of creativity development, we shall pay attention to the processes of symbolic mediation (internalization and externalization processes inclusive). Recognizing that creativity is the essence of human existence, deliberations will be given to facilitate creative expressions of a young child in the context of kindergartens, home, and community.
outcome: 1. Understand the nature of aesthetic experience and its role in the early years of development; 2. Understand the interrelated development of empathetic understanding, imagination, and creativity through the arts;  3. Become familiar with different forms of art and their richness; 4. Demonstrate the ability to design activities for young children in order to enhance children's appreciation and creative expressions of arts; 5.deepen their own experience of play as an ideal form for creative expressions; 5. Cultivate their creativity through the process of working on the group project and the individual essay; and 6. Enhance their sensitivity to practical issues related to the aesthetic experience and creative expressions of a young child in the local context.

title: Introduction to Educational Research
description: This course will introduce to the students the basic constructs of educational research and prepare them for carrying out a project of field inquiry into early childhood education, which is required by the program. The purposes and processes of various types of educational research, such as ethnographical research, survey research, experimental research, ex post factor research, action research, and etc. will be illustrated with examples of educational studies. The primary statistical tools will be demonstrated to help the participants understand how the tools can be appropriately applied to educational research. In learning and understanding the various aspects of educational research, the participants will be provided with the opportunity to experience how to generate and shape a research question and how to choose a research method to approach to the question.Students’ competence is assessed by their performance in writing coherently and fluently a proposal for a potential research project, demonstrating sound ideas of identifying a research question, selecting appropriate research designs to address the question, and presenting clear understanding of the requirements for each component of a research project. Specific learning outcomes (as shown below) and assessment criteria are aligned with each individual task.
outcome: A. Acquire a knowledge base about the basic concepts of educational research. B. Understand the purposes, characteristics, and limitations of the different research methods in educational research. C. Apply the concepts to critically read educational research reports. D. Develop a proposal for small-scale independent research.

title: Supporting Preschool Children with Special Educational Needs
description: This course aims to provide students with theoretical foundations in selected areas of special needs, and to help them to understand possible learning difficulties that preschool children with these special needs would encounter. Selected areas of special needs include: (i) autism spectrum disorder; (ii) emotional and behavioral disorders; (iii) specific language impairment; (iv) physical disabilities; and (v) intellectual disabilities. For each kind of special need, students will learn its characteristics, causes, and provision of special education in Hong Kong. Besides, this course will also prepare students for developing essential intervention strategies and techniques to help children with learning difficulties. Students will also work in small groups, under the supervision of the instructor, to conduct case studies in order to strengthen their knowledge of the learning difficulties of selected groups of children.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should be able to: 1. To acquire basic principles of identification and knowledge in educating children with various types of special-needs children in early childhood 2. To gain an understanding of provision of preschool special education in Hong Kong 3. To begin to critically evaluate current issues related to the education of preschool students with special educational needs 4. To develop relevant intervention strategies to facilitate student development and enhance development and learning in early childhood

title: Assessment for the Development and Learning of Young Children
description: This course provides students a basic understanding of the assessment principles and methods for teachers of young children from three to eight years of age. The foci of the courses are: 1) the basic concepts of educational and psychological assessment; 2) the purposes and processes of a variety of assessment methods currently used to assess and understand learning and development of young children; and 3) challenges in assessing young children from psychological, educational, and cultural perspectives. Students are expected to improve their educational practice by acquiring a working knowledge of appropriate assessment and gaining an understanding of the methods of observation, interview, standardized testing, and alternative assessment approaches for young children.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should be able to demonstrates: 1. the understanding of the purposes, characteristics, and limitations of different kinds of assessments for young children, and the principles and ethics of appropriate assessment; 2. become familiar with a variety of formal and informal assessment methods, including interviewing, observation, standardized testing, and alternative assessment; 3. develop knowledge of a repertoire of effective assessment methods that can be used to continuously monitor children’s progress in different areas of learning and development; and 4. acquire a working knowledge of basic measurement concepts, including reliability, validity, norm-referenced, criterion-referenced, and standardization.

title: Counselling Young Children
description: This course introduces basic counselling skills for working with preschool children in response to a variety of developmental and/or adjustment issues. Topics to be covered include: ways to build rapport with young children, use of toys, drama, art, music and other creative techniques to work with children with various abilities. Throughout the course, students are expected to gain better understanding of children's feelings and needs, and become more aware of the ways to respond to children. Such an understanding will enable students to facilitate the development of positive emotional relationship and improve behaviors of children, which ultimately allow more learning to take place. The roles of family and school in working with young children will be emphasized.
outcome: By the end of the course, students are expected to: i. Acquire better knowledge in understanding social-emotional needs of children ii. Apply basic counseling skills in building better teacher-student relationship that can enhance children’s overall development iii. Gain ideas on the use of different techniques such as play, music, art, and stories to help children explore emotions iv. Relate better to parents and be able to work collaboratively with them to enhance the development of children v. Appreciate the therapeutic powers of play in counseling children  (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary)

title: Fundamental Movement Skill and Rhythmic Activity for Young Children
description: This course is to develop knowledge and understanding of the learning, teaching and assessing process in relation to fundamental movement skills (FMS). Students will be introduced to both theoretical and applied aspects of movement education for young children. There will be a focus on planning and implementing purposeful activities which will promote FMS and cater for individual differences in the early years. Students will also be trained to observe and assess young children movement abilities using the key components of the movement patterns associated with individual FMS. Through participation, students will build a range of FMS and rhythmic activities to be taught in early childhood settings.
outcome: After taking this course, students will be able to: 1. Understand child physical, cognitive and affective development and underpinning theories of motor skill learning and development in young children. 2. Understand FMS and movement concepts, and describe how they interact with one another to promote acquisition of FMS and physical literacy in children. 3. Demonstrate application of understanding of movement concepts and the skill components for teaching and assessment of young children’s proficiency in a variety of FMS. 4. Plan and deliver developmentally appropriate FMS and rhythmic activities in a critical and innovative approach to support physical, cognitive and affective development of young children. 5. Identify /diagnose the problems, and develop creative and innovative solutions to the problems of motor skill acquisition among young children. 6. Demonstrate application of professional ethics and values in planning and delivering developmentally appropriate FMS and rhythmic activities.
syllabus: 1. Gross Motor Skill Development in the Early Years 2. Overview of Physical Literacy and Fundamental Movement Skills 3. Importance and Benefits of Fundamental Movement Skills Proficiency in Young Children 4. Strategies for Fundamental Movement Skills Development in Young Children 5. Learning about Fundamental Movement Skills and their Components 6. Understanding Movement Concepts through Structured Play and Games 7. Practical FMS and Rhythmic Activities for Classroom Application 8. Observation and Assessment Tools for the Early Years 9. Integration Movement Opportunities in Early Childhood Curriculum 10. Developmentally Appropriate Movement Practice for Young Children: Design and Presentation  11. Research and Trend of Motor Skill Development in Young Children

title: Values Education in Early Childhood Education
description: This course aims to explicate the theoretical foundations of moral education, character education and values education as well as to illuminate their limitations and possibilities associated with the preschool and educational contexts of Hong Kong. Issues on caring, character formation, philosophy for children, moral meanings in children stories, children's thinking of selves, moral and social rules, sex education, care to environment, pedagogies for conflict resolution and moral education will be discussed. It serves to help participants reflect on their own values and on the ways they teach values.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are expected to: 1. understand the key theories and principles of moral education, character education and values education; 2. analyse selected issues related to moral education, character education and values education in the preschool and educational contexts of Hong Kong; and 3. reflect on their own values and the ways they teach values in preschools.

title: Guided Study in Issues of Child Development
description: This course is an application of a student-orientated approach to teaching intended to nurture students to become independent learners, professional teachers of young children, and reflective early childhood education practitioners. Students are required to pursue an issue of child development of their choice, build their understanding of the issue, and then share their personal views of the issue.Students’ performance is assessed according to their demonstration of logical thinking and thorough analysis of various issues from different theoretical perspectives with the support of empirical evidence.

title: Contemporary Issues in Early Childhood Education
description: This course is to provide students with a venue to look into current issues and trends in early childhood education (ECE) in Hong Kong (HK). It focuses on the conceptual and methodological backgrounds of complex issues resulting from demands of the changing society on the education system in general and on ECE in particular. Topics may include (i) impact of the territory-wide education reforms and medium of instruction policies on local ECE; (ii) early literacy and bilingual education; (iii) interface between kindergarten and primary school; (iv) diverse ECE and care service and inclusive education for children; (v) quality criteria to evaluate services of ECE and care; (vi) impacts of media and IT on early childhood; (vii) impacts of advances in brain research on ECE and (viii) training and development of kindergarten teachers.
outcome: At the end of this course, students are expected to:  1. Appreciate how changes in the society as well as in our understandings of human development give rise to new interpretations of the recurring issues in ECE; 2. Understand how different perspectives on the issues have affected and shaped thoughts and practices in the local ECE context; and 3. Develop the sense and capacity to not only comprehend but also act on the issues.

title: Research Project
description: Students will work individually to pursue independent study on approved topics and areas under the supervision of teachers appointed by the Department/Faculty of Education.- coverage of the literature review leading to the research question(s)- description of how the research was done- quality of the discussion based on the findings- proper citation of references used- organization and clarity of the whole research paper- length (excluding references) within the specified limits
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will have a hand-on experience of the process in conducting an educational research and be able to: 1. conduct literature review, formulate a research question, design a suitable research, collect and analyze data, summarize key research findings and discuss them cohesively, and 2. acquire an in-depth understanding in a selected issue on early childhood education which is significant to child development and learning. (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcomes as and whenever necessary)
syllabus: Students are expected to identify an area for research and to conceptualize a research study based on the review of literature in the selected area. Students can utilize a range of research methodologies and designs to address their research questions. The basic requirements of this project are listed below: 1. The research topic has to be approved by the faculty supervisor. 2. The research study has to be based on a body of previous and current theories and/or research literature. The research question(s) should be specified clearly. 3. The research report should be written in a scholarly manner, and its quality should match those that are required for individual research work for an undergraduate degree.

title: Internship
description: This course provides opportunities for students to put knowledge and skills they learned from the program into practice via engaging in a real-life experience in the child care related/ education sector. Examples of activities for this internship include: working with individual children to facilitate their cognitive and social-emotional development, conducting programs relating to parent education, assisting in research projects, assisting in the promotion of activities in relation to children’s physical and mental health. Students will be evaluated based upon a collection of reflection papers, a group presentation and an evaluation from the on-site supervisor/course coordinator.- Evaluation from on-site supervisor/course instructor according to the criteria agreed upon (at the site visit) as well as those listed in the internship appraisal form.These include but not limited to: responsibility, work attitude, preparation for the assigned tasks, and interaction with the target group(s)- Content of the sharing in addressing professional growth and ECE-related issues in the group presentation- Organization, clarify and level of reflection in the internship report
outcome: After taking this course, students will be able to – i. apply knowledge and skills in child development to practical situation of the early childhood sector; ii. effectively perform duties at the internship site in a professional manner; iii. develop effective communication and problem solving skills for personal and career development; iv. reflect on personal and professional development based on the learning experience; and v. identify their interests in future career pursuit.
syllabus: Students are expected to complete an internship of around 40 hours. The placement site is arranged based on students’ preference/interests/abilities and is upon mutual agreement. As the vacancy in each site varies, it is not guaranteed that students will be allocated to their first preference.   Given the nature of the serving population, the number of hours per session varies. It can be ranged from 1 hour to full-day (6 hours) per visit. This internship is organized during periods when students have no institutional commitment. Special arrangement of placement period could be accepted with prior application and approval with internship course instructor.   Students are not allowed to take leave during the internship period once the placement and details are confirmed. In case of medical issues or any unforeseen situation, the student is expected to discuss the make-up arrangement with the course instructor at the soonest possible time.
